title: Account was hacked, then was banned in the span of a couple of hours
body:
As stated in the title, my account got hacked while I was at PAX Aus and someone played on my account for 4 games, then got banned for third party software. I have always been pretty uptight when it comes to maintaining the integrity of my passwords, using different ones on different websites, not sharing accounts, creating strong passwords, so I'd like to hope that there was a security breach on Riot's side, but it is possible that it's not their fault. 

It's just kind of strange that for a company of this size that there is no sort of 2 step verification to log in on a new device, or any email that is sent out if you log on a new device. I've already registered my phone number for when clash was around in OCE, so I would have gladly used 2 factor if it was offered. 

Is there any advice that anyone to give me that would help me help/prove my innocence and get my account unbanned?

replies.body:
You'll want to submit an Account Recovery ticket to [Support](https://support.riotgames.com/hc/en-us/requests/new) (use the "Recover my account" option, you'll need to be logged out to do so). That will start the account recovery process, during which the Support staff will ask you a series of questions related to the account to help with verification (don't worry if you can't answer all of them, you just need enough to prove beyond reasonable doubt), any additional information not available via Riot or 3rd party services will help with this. If the process goes smoothly, they should be able to verify the compromise period, and reverse any actions resulting from that.

One thing to note regarding account recovery services is that any history of account sharing (in any form) may negatively impact your chances of successfully resolving the issue.

As someone who takes extra care with account security, you'd probably know how to handle a compromise situation, but I'll give you all the standard advice anyway. Definitely run an anti-virus scan with whatever software you're using on any personal computers you've used recently, it may not show anything but always best to check in these situations (I'd personally recommend Malwarebytes Anti-Malware [free] for manual scans, as it seems to pick up more than other anti-virus software in my experience, but up to you). Also a good idea to recommend the same for anyone if you've used their computer for LoL recently, in particular public computers carry extra risk in this way. 

Also a good idea to check security for any important accounts, such as emails, banks etc. and I'd also recommend you check out the website https://haveibeenpwned.com/ as it is a great resource for tracking down compromises, particularly across multiple services.

Thank you so much for the help. I'm strugging to answer some of the questions such as "the first rp item you bought and date" and a couple of other ones since it was in 2015. In November last year, I requested to download my data, which includes everything stored about my account. This includes rp purchases and rp uses, however these do not have dates, rather their transaction numbers etc. Would it be helpful if I sent the file? Or should I just guess the dates since my first rp purchase was with a gift card and there was no email receipt.

In addition, to what HeartVine has said, any information that is unique to the account but not visible on it is useful for determining ownership. 

Naturally the earlier the better, but if you don't remember your first RP purchase what about the first champion you bought? Are there any particular skins you remember buying on release dates? Were they in any bundles or on their own? Do you maybe have a dated screenshot of when you got your first Mastery 5?

Any of this sort of information is useful, but especially info from early on and coupled with dates, even if they are only approximate ones.

I'd recommend you make your best estimate of the item and date, though you could send the file as a well if you think it will help (make sure they're aware why you're sending it). I'm not sure how they'll respond to the account data file, since it can be access through email, but no harm in trying. As I said earlier, you shouldn't need to answer every question perfectly, all they need is enough to reasonably conclude you're the original user.

Also, 2fa will be coming Soon(TM) with the introduction of the new login flow!

https://na.leagueoflegends.com/en/news/client/client-features/saved-login-credentials-coming-soon?ref=rss

The update also has some under-the-hood changes to prepare for additional optimizations to the client in the upcoming years: two-factor authentication, background patching, and yes, one day, support for our next game.

There are a few reasons you wouldn't get unbanned in such a scenario. Having previously shared the account, being unable to verify ownership of the account, being hacked by a friend or by someone who would otherwise make the compromise impossible to verify, or having been repeatedly compromised in the past are the usual suspects, but not the only ones.

If you feel that none of those were the case and that your appeal shouldn't have been denied, then you can always reply to the ticket and ask for a second opinion, detailing why you disagree with the decision. WIthout knowing the details, I couldn't give you any idea of the outcome of such.

There have been a few cases in the past of bans for illicit third party activity being denied appeal because the compromise was missed or not properly verified, though none that I know of recently, and again without details I couldn't say if your case fits into this category.

Like I said though, there are various reasons that would result in Support denying an appeal, or being unable to verify the compromise so I can't guarantee anything.

If it was a friend or family member who had access to your PC, there wouldn't be any way to verify that it was actually compromised, and the *physical* security of your account comes solely down to you since Riot can realistically only protect you in the digital space (and even then, some responsibility still falls to you).

I don't know if that's the case here, it's just a possibility. Without the details (which a 3rd party like myself won't get access too) there isn't really any other advice I can offer. It's possible something was missed, and if you make anew ticket now it will be resolved. It's possible they can't confirm the compromise and there's nothing they can do.

As a friend who used to play with ShroomJuice regularly before this happened, the whole situation is to be honest incredibly frustrating and annoying . 

Now I know it is difficult for Riot as they do want to keep their game cheat/hacker free, so yes banning a potentially compromised account would make sense. However looking at the OCE support forums over the last month, the amount of compromised accounts being banned for hacking/3rd Party program use is pretty insane. In my opinion this may have led to a few incredibly frustrated, innocent players having their accounts permanently banned. 

Looking at the posts throughout the forums it honestly seems to me that either; someone is running rampant through the OCE servers with hacking/cheating software (I actually had someone admit to hacking on one forum) or the Riot OCE servers have had a data leak. Either of which may be true however I believe the former to be more likely.

After the responses I've received from various sources I know this post probably won't help my friend get his account back in any way whatsoever, however I feel like I need so say something because if this hacking, cheating then ban problem continues Riot may find a portion of their Australian audience leave the game for good.   

To be completely honest the fact that (making a slight assumption here) that Riot (a billion dollar company) is unable to either track login locations or determine suspicious activity from that data (if they can track it) seems a little silly. Like i said above though I don't think anything I say can help my friend. I do hope however that from bringing this up Riot could perhaps bring some methods of account security to the game, as to stop this from happening again. Because really as popular as this game is not having a simple security measure like 2 Factor Authentication is unacceptable.  *Also yes I know Riot has 2FA in development however the last update on that feature was 4 months ago. * 

TL;DR - Am frustrated that my friend ShroomJuice and other OCE players have been getting banned due to hackers, and think Riot should add more priority to introducing more security factors to the game. Because hearing "it's your fault you didn't secure you account more", when you did is really damn frustrating.

Cheers, KurtForrester :)

It's frustrating yes, but the policy for compromised then banned accounts is that they generally don't stay banned. As I have mentioned in my other comments, there are exceptions to this rule, but the average player can recover such an account with relative ease so long as they can verify ownership.
Yeah, he has gone through all the verification process however he still remains banned much to our/his frustration.

If he has verified ownership of the account, and it's been verified that the actions taken that resulted in the ban were not taken by him, then that should be the end of it and the account should be recovered.

That it hasn't been speaks to either a mistake (which can be rectified by asking for a second opinion), or to something else being involved.

Without the details, there is nothing more I can offer.

~~I'm not aware of anything that would result in your tickets being deleted. Closed yes, but not deleted. You should be able to view all of your current and past tickets on the support site.~~

Account recovery tickets are deleted once they are resolved and/or closed to prevent any further intrusions from seeing that information (because that is the information that you need to recover the account).

If you still have access to the email associated with the account, then you can probably see the replies there since as far as I know all tickets and responses will still come through as an email as well. If you don't have access to the email associated with the account, there's a lot of hoops to jump through, but it's still possible to retrieve those tickets.

At this stage I would *again* recommend just submitting another ticket asking for a review of the compromise and revocation of actions taken as a result of the compromise. I would also strongly recommend getting the associated email changed to one you *do* have access to if you haven't already.
